title: People 'hear' flashes due to disinhibited flow of signals around the brain, suggests study

title_detail.value: People 'hear' flashes due to disinhibited flow of signals around the brain, suggests study

summary: A synaesthesia-like effect in which people 'hear' silent flashes or movement, such as in popular 'noisy GIFs' and memes, could be due to a reduction of inhibition of signals that travel between visual and auditory areas of the brain, according to a new study. It was also found that musicians taking part in the study were significantly more likely to report experiencing visual ear than non-musician participants.
